This code shows the overall structure appropriate for a game view window.

startPlaying

public void startPlaying()
this is called by the game controller when all players have connected and the first player is about to be allowed to make his first move. This may be a new game, or a game being restored, or a player rejoining a game. You can override or encapsulate this method.

Specified by:
startPlaying in interface online.game.ViewGameProtocol
Overrides:
startPlaying in class online.game.commonCanvas

encodeScreenZone

public java.lang.String encodeScreenZone(int x,
                                         int y,
                                         java.awt.Point p)
translate the mouse coordinate x,y into a size-independent representation presumably based on the cell grid. This is used to transmit our mouse position to the other players and spectators, so it will be displayed at approximately the same visual spot on their screen. The results of this function only have to be interpreted by decodeScreenZone(java.lang.String, int, int) Some trickier logic may be needed if the board has several orientations, or if some mouse activity should be censored.

Specified by:
encodeScreenZone in interface online.game.ViewerProtocol
Overrides:
encodeScreenZone in class online.game.commonCanvas

updatePlayerTime

public void updatePlayerTime(long inc,
                             online.game.commonPlayer p)
update the players clocks. The normal thing is to tick the clocks only for the player whose turn it is. Games with a simtaneous action phase need to do something more complicated.

Specified by:
updatePlayerTime in interface online.game.ViewGameProtocol
Overrides:
updatePlayerTime in class online.game.commonCanvas
Parameters:
inc - the increment (in milliseconds) to add
p - the current player, normally the player to update.

setLocalBounds

public void setLocalBounds(int x,
                           int y,
                           int width,
                           int height)
this is the main method to do layout of the board and other widgets. I don't use swing or any other standard widget kit, or any of the standard layout managers. they just don't have the flexibility to produce the results I want. Your milage may vary, and of course you're free to use whatever layout and drawing methods you want to. However, I do strongly encourage making a UI that is resizable within reasonable limits, and which has the main "board" object at the left. The basic layout technique used here is to start with a cell which is about the size of a board square, and lay out all the other object relative to the board or to one another. The rectangles don't all have to be on grid points, and don't have to be nonoverlapping, just so long as the result generally looks good. When "extraactions" is available, a menu opion "show rectangles" works with the "addRect" mechanism to help visualize the layout.

Specified by:
setLocalBounds in class online.common.exCanvas

Execute

public boolean Execute(online.game.commonMove mm,
                       online.game.replayMode replay)
Execute a move by the other player, or as a result of local mouse activity, or retrieved from the move history, or replayed form a stored game.

Specified by:
Execute in class online.game.commonCanvas
Parameters:
mm - the parameter is a commonMove so the superclass commonCanvas can request execution of moves in a generic way.
Returns:
true if all went well. Normally G.Error would be called if anything went seriously wrong.

ParseNewMove

public online.game.commonMove ParseNewMove(java.lang.String st)
parse a move specifier on behalf of the current player. This is called by the "game" object when it receives a move from the other player. Note that it may be called while we are in review mode, so the current state of the board should not be considered.

Specified by:
ParseNewMove in class online.game.commonCanvas

verifyGameRecord

public void verifyGameRecord()
this method is called from deep inside PerformAndTransmit, at the point where the move has been executed and the history has been edited. It's purpose is to verify that the history accurately represents the current state of the game, and that the fundamental game machinery is in a consistent and reproducible state. Basically, it works by creating a duplicate board resetting it and feeding the duplicate the entire history, and then verifying that the duplicate is the same as the original board. It's perfectly ok, during debugging and development, to temporarily change this method into a no-op, but be warned if you do this because it is throwing an error, there are other problems that need to be fixed eventually.

Overrides:
verifyGameRecord in class online.game.commonCanvas

StartDragging

public void StartDragging(online.common.HitPoint hp)
the preferred mouse gesture style is to let the user "pick up" objects by simply clicking on them, but we also allow him to click and drag. StartDragging is called when he has done this.

Specified by:

StopDragging

public void StopDragging(online.common.HitPoint hp)
this is called on "mouse up". We may have been just clicking on something, or we may have just finished a click-drag-release. We're guaranteed just one mouse up, no bounces.

drawFixedElements

public void drawFixedElements(java.awt.Graphics gc)
draw the deep unchangeable objects, including those that might be rather expensive to draw. This background layer is used as a backdrop to the rest of the activity. in our cease, we draw the board and the chips on it.

gameType

public java.lang.String gameType()
this is a token or tokens that initialize the variation and set immutable parameters such as the number of players and the random key for the game. It can be more than one token, which ought to be parseable by performHistoryInitialization(java.util.StringTokenizer)

startRobot

public online.game.commonPlayer startRobot(online.game.commonPlayer p,
                                           online.game.commonPlayer runner,
                                           online.common.OnlineConstants.Bot bot)
start the robot. This is used to invoke a robot player. Mainly this needs to know the class for the robot and any initialization it requires. Normally the the robot player p is also returned. Raj (and other simultaneous play games) might return a different player, the one actually started.
